text: I'm mark permit the doubles Lucia
athlete for the United States Vancouver
will be my fifth Olympic Games my
doubles teammate Brian Martin and I won
at silver medal in the 2002 Games and a
bronze in 1998 I'm going to talk about
the sled to start and how we steer the
sled going down the track at 90 miles an
hour
our custom-built sled is a fibreglass
pod with two handles the two runners on
the bottom have flexible curved sections
that we use to steer
once we're seated on the sled we're
ready for the start a crucial part of
the race we begin by rocking back and
forth a couple of times to synchronize
our movements as we reach the handles
our third time forward we pause putting
us in the Block position this prepares
us for our final thrust backwards from
the block we push back as hard as we can
fully extending our bodies like loading
a spring this is called the compression
phase and once we hit the back point we
transition into the pull phase here we
try to get out of the compression as
fast as we can exploding out of the
handles pulling with our shoulders and
upper back to ensure that we're pulling
as one Brian clutches on the straps tied
around my fingers and arms in order to
get the most power and momentum our
hands and arms must leave the handle at
straight angles once we're on the track
we use our gloves to paddle through the
first 10 to 15 feet of the track our
gloves have spikes taped onto some of
the fingers for traction as the top men
I try to stay as flat and aerodynamic as
possible the bottom driver acts like a
suspension trying to keep the ride
smooth going in and out of the curves
the steel runners on the sled bottom
have a slight arc so as we speed along
only about four or five inches of steel
touched the ice at any given time we
call these riding surfaces the balance
points because I see where we're going
I control most of the steering to
initiate a turn I turn my head in the
direction of the curve Brian as the back
driver can steer harder because he is in
contact with the sled and he takes his
cues from me for a left-hand turn I
turned my head in the direction of the
curve then Brian starts to steer by
pushing down with his left shoulder and
I push down with my right foot
this causes the sled to twist the
runners flex and the balance points
shift making the sled turn we call this
hook steering the moments before each
turn are critical there's a theoretical
perfect line for each curve when the
curve pulls the sled up above this line
I need to drive down to meet this
line and when the curve wants to pull
the sled down below this line then I
need to drive up in order to meet this
line if your finish time depends on
making the least amount of mistakes
allowing gravity to do its work
